Direct application of antibacterial agents into foods gives limited advantages because bioactive ingredients may be partially inactivated, neutralized, or easily diffused when contacting with the food matrix. Hence, the aim of this study is to investigate the application of lipid-based nanocarriers as delivery systems for antibacterial ingredients. In this regard, several types of these carriers such as nanoliposomes, nanoemulsions, solid lipid nanoparticles (SLNs), and nanostructured lipid carriers (NLCs) are explored. This study seeks to cover the important challenges of lipid-based nanocarriers including structures and characteristics, properties, production methods, advantages and drawbacks, and their applications to encapsulate antibacterial compounds effectively, particularly in food systems. However, for more scrutiny inspection of the functionality of lipid-based nanocarriers, we have gathered and discussed the studies related to the antibiotic-loaded lipid-based nanoparticles. Also, the role of such nanocarriers in active packaging systems when combining with edible coatings or films is discussed.

1. Introduction
Regarding the estimated six hundredmillion cases of foodborne diseases annually, unsafe foods are a serious risk to human health and economies worldwide. Foodborne diseases in developing countries cost at least one hundred billion dollars a year, with this cost exceeding
five hundredmillion dollars for twenty-eight countries, according to the recent study of World Bank. Majority of foodborne diseases are related to pathogenic bacteria such as Escherichia coli, Salmonella, Campylobacter, and Clostridium [1]. One of the serious issues nowadays is challenges associated with the consumption of foods contaminated with antibacterial-resistant bacteria. There are obvious scientific evidences that foods of plant origin may be a vehicle of antimicrobial-resistant bacteria. Due to the importance of such bacteria, the 39th session of the Codex Alimentarius Commission (CAC), in a report, agreed to

reestablish ad hoc Codex Intergovernmental Task Force on antimicrobial resistance with the purposes of revising the current Codex Code of “Practice to Minimise and Contain Antimicrobial Resistance” (CAC/RCP 61-2005) and developing new regulation on surveillance programs related to foodborne antimicrobial-resistant bacteria [2]. In this report, it has been mentioned that 25% of foods of plant origin are contaminated with bacteria resistant to one ormore antimicrobial substances. Besides, irrigation water, aquaculture products such as shrimp and shellfish, crops, and soils are other important sources contaminated with antibacterial-resistant bacteria. Many approaches have planned to decrease the risk of such organisms, including farming practice, natural antibacterials, lactic acid bacteria, bacteriophage, and nanotechnology [3]. Todays, nanotechnology has a big contribution in dealing with foodborne diseases.
According to "National Nanotechnology Initiative" of USA, nanotechnology is commonly defined as the knowledge and the control of materials at the scales of 1 to 100 nm, inwhich unique phenomenamake the novel applications possible [4]. The reason is the special reactions of atoms and molecules in the scale of nano, resulting in the creation of new and unique applications [5]. Nanotechnology is employed in many areas, such as the usage of nanoparticles in production of packaging materials, formulation of foods with a high bioavailability, cellular and molecular applications, and the production of nanocarrier systems loaded with bioactive ingredients [6].
Nanocarriers are considered as a substantial part of nanotechnology with the purpose of the entrapment of bioactive compounds to control their release [7,8]. McClements et al. [9] explained that these systems are carriers, designing for the protection of bioactives from oxidation, crystallization, precipitation, denaturation, pH variation, temperature, moisture, ionic strength changes, absorption, diffusion, and biochemical reactions. Nanocarriers likewise should provide the possibility of controlled and stable release of bioactives in targeted place/cell, which this factor is under the influence of ionic strength, pH, microbial load, and enzyme activity. In comparison with micro-carriers, nanocarriers show a higher thermodynamic and kinetic stability and have a higher surface-to-volume ratio; hence, they exhibit a better role in improving the bioavailability and solubility of lipid-based bioactive ingredients [10,11]. On the other hand, nanocarriers can penetrate into the targeted pathogenicmicroorganism via the endocytosis and release their antimicrobial contents [12].
Nanocarrier systems are usually divided into five groups of lipidbased, nature-inspiring, special equipment-based, biopolymer-based, and miscellaneous nanocarriers [5,13]. Polymer types of these systems have less development compared to lipid ones in the market owing to some limitations of polymer-based nanocarrier systems, such as possibility to be toxic, restriction of production in high volume, low bioavailability, and requirement of organic solvents [7,14]. Also, many bioactive compounds, such as tocopherols, carotenoids, and phytosterols have hydrophobic entity; therefore, encapsulation of these compounds in polymer materials needs proper colloidal dispersions [15,16]. In contrast, the presence of digestible lipids at carrier systems facilitates their absorption from the intestines. Lipid-based nanocarrier systems possess advantages, including high surface-to-volume ratio, high loading capacity, and high stability at the environment. However, they have some drawbacks, such as lack of uniformitywhen loading, requirement of surfactants in high concentrations, and the possibility of aggregation and precipitation [17–19]. One of the most outstanding features of lipid-based nanocarriers in food technology compared to other delivery systems such as biopolymeric carriers is feasibility of their production in industrial scales.
Lipid-based nanocarrier systems generally consist of four types of nanoemulsions, nanoliposomes, solid lipid nanoparticles (SLNs), and nanostructured lipid carriers (NLCs). Some features of these nanocarriers are given in Table 1 [7]. Also, the fifth type, named lipiddrug conjugates (LDCs) has been designed and used in pharmaceutical industries. Another group of nanocarriers which can be considered in
this group are surfactant-based nanocargos such as niosomes and cubosomes/hexosomes [8,19]. The selection of each type of these systemsneeds considering several parameters including: (1) encapsulation efficacy, (2) toxicity, (3) their reactions with the other components of food matrix, (4) physical and chemical stability, determined by indices of size, zeta potential, polydispersity index (PDI), etc., (5) ability to be produced in high volumes, and (6) cost of formulation.
Since the direct use of antibacterials or antibiotics is limited owing to many reasons such as creation of antibacterial-resistant bacteria or restrictions associated with foods, application of lipid-based nanocarriers containing antibacterial agents plays an outstanding role in the fight against foodborne illnesses, particularly bacteria resistant to antibiotics. These nanocarriers, due to the inherent properties such as less toxicity, similarity to the membrane of cells, having potential to penetrate through cell walls and membranes, reduced size, increased surface to volume ratio, delivering a concentrated amount of antibacterials or antibiotics to targeted organisms, etc., can be promising tools in many fields, particularly food technologies
In overall, the main goal of this study is to demonstrate the importance of lipid based nanocarriers for improving the biological activity of antibacterial agents such as natural or synthetic antibiotics, essential oils, plant extracts, etc. against food-related bacteria using such nanodelivery systems.

sections.heading: 2. Importance of antimicrobial agents in foods
sections.text:
Antimicrobial agents are ingredients which can inhibit themicrobial growth or kill them. The incorporation of such compounds into different food products is usually necessary in assuring food safety. The addition of salts, sodium nitrate, essential oils, polyphenols, metals, fatty acids, and bacteriocins are examples of their application in food industries [20,21]. Antibacterial agents commonly execute their activity against bacteria through several mechanisms, including pore-forming in membranes,flocculation of intracellular contents, inhibiting cell-wall synthesis, altering cytoplasmic membrane, binding nucleic acids, preventing enzymatic activity, inhibiting nucleic-acid synthesis, producing reactive oxygen species, interferences with nutrient assimilation, etc. [22–25]. In the food industries, these ingredients are considered as important parts of hurdle technology to improve the safety and prolong the shelf-life of food products.
However, direct application of antimicrobial agents in foods gives limited advantages because bioactive ingredients may be partially inactivated, neutralized, or easily diffused when contacting with the food matrix; on the other hand, antimicrobials usually have a low solubility, low physical and chemical stability, and may have adverse impacts on sensorial properties of foods [26]. In other words, bioactive antimicrobial compounds can interface with the physicochemical and sensorial properties of foods such as color, taste, flavor, texture, appearance, and stability. Besides, such bioactive agents may encounter with many deteriorative factors, concerning the processing steps and storage of foods, which denaturation, cyclization, and oxidation are some of them. Therefore, researchers have focused on a number of plans to deal with these difficulties. Lipid-based nanocarriers, with the capability to encapsulate and protect antimicrobial bioactives, are one of themost effective strategies [27]. Encapsulation of antibacterial agents, along with antibacterial impacts, has also been reported to be effective against biofilms through preventing their adhesion onto surfaces and destroying their formed films [28]. Many biological tests exist to evaluate the antimicrobial activity of encapsulated bioactives such as simple culturing and counting, time-killing, disk diffusion, etc. In the majority of studies, three parameters have been applied to investigate and compare the influence of antimicrobials in pure and nanoencapsulated forms including the inhibition zone (disk diffusion), determining the bacterial growth, minimum bactericidal/inhibition concentration (MIC), and minimum bactericidal concentration (MBC).

3. Antimicrobials loaded within nanoliposomes
Liposomes are carriers, containing polar lipids (such as phosphatidylethanolamine or phosphatidylcholine) or a combination of polar lipids with ergosterol or cholesterol, which participate in creating bilayer structures [29]. Many studies have employed cholesterol as lipid and phosphatidylcholine as emulsifier to produce liposomes. They have spherical shapes in dimensions of nano to micro. These structures contain single or multiple amphiphilic membranes. Nanoliposomes, possessing single layer membranes are divided into two kinds of single unilamellar vesicles (SUVs) with sizes smaller than 30 nm and large unilamellar vesicles (LUVs) with sizes between 30 to 100 nm [30]. Also, liposomes, having multiple membranes are in two types of multilamellar vesicles (MLVs) and multivesicular vesicles (MVVs) [31]. These carriers can entrap and release a wide spectrum of hydrophilic, hydrophobic, and amphiphilic bioactives owing to the presence of both aqueous and lipid phases in their structures. In the vesicles of liposomes, polar groups of phospholipids have developed towards the aqueous phase, existed at the inside and outside of liposomes, while hydrophobic hydrocarbon tails present into membranes layers.
The selection of nanoliposomes are preferred to liposomes, because they provide more surface-to-volume ratios and have the potential to enhance bioavailability, improve controlled release, and increment solubility [32]. Several methods have been devised to produce nanoliposomes, including mechanical methods (like sonication, extrusion, high pressure homogenization, supercritical fluid, ethanol
injection, dehydration and rehydration, microfluidization, thin film hydration, etc.) and non-mechanicalmethods (like reverse phase evaporation). Another advantage of nanoliposomes is their ability to deliver the bioactive ingredients into the targeted cell, called targetability. Actually, the similar structure of nanoliposomeswith cell’smembranes facilitates their combination with cells and the release of bioactive compounds, particularly antimicrobial agents into them. Also, the surface of nanoliposomes has the potential to be modified by several ligands, such as antibodies, peptides, and aptamers [33]. For example, the attachment of polyethylene glycol (PEG) onto the surface of nanoliposomes increments their stability [34]. In comparison with other carriers, nanoliposomes provide a better chemical stability and protection, concerning the sensitive bioactive compounds in conditions of high water activity. The most important disadvantages of liposomes is the burst release of their contents, which todays, it has been fixed with several approaches like using a chitosan polymer as a coating material [35]. All of these features have caused nanoliposomes to beused as an effective nanocarrier for encapsulating antibacterial compounds.
One of the verified test, showing the antibacterial activity is MIC. Several studies have claimed that the encapsulation of antibacterial bioactives by nanoliposomes have incremented their antibacterial strength by decreasing the MIC values. For instance, Khatibi, et al. [36] revealed that the MIC value of Zataria multiflora Boiss. essential oil against E. coli O157:H7 in the free and nanoliposome loaded forms were 0.03% and 0.015% (v/v), respectively. 4. Antimicrobial-loaded nanoemulsions
An emulsion is a system, containing two phases, in which one phase is dispersed at the other one, forming minute droplets in a diameter range of 0.1 to 100 μm [37]. This system is thermodynamically unstable,
but, it can be stabilized via the addition of an emulsifying agent (emulsifier). The dispersed phase is known as the discontinuous phase or internal phase, whereas the outer phase is known as the continuous phase, external phase, or dispersion medium. The emulsifier is an intermediate or interphase agent [38].
Nanoemulsions, submicron emulsions or miniemulsions are three terms used for a colloidal particulate delivery system formed through the dispersion of two immiscible liquids by means of an emulsifying agent along with the physical share-induced rupturing [39]. The range of their size varies between 10 to 1000 nm; however, they typically present at the range of 20 to 200 nm. The main dissimilarity between emulsion and nanoemulsion is in the shape and size of dispersed droplets. Three types of nanoemulsions exist: (a) water in oil (W/O) nanoemulsions for encapsulating hydrophilic substances, (b), oil in water (O/W) nanoemulsions for encapsulating lipophilic bioactive agents, and (c) bi-continuous nanoemulsions [40].
Numerous methods have been employed to form nanoemulsions with an acceptable stability. In this concern, two groups of techniques, called mechanical (high intensity or high energy) and non-mechanical
(low intensity or low energy) techniques have been developed [41,42]. Mechanical methods use high shear forces to break up and intermix water and oil phases by generating turbulent, intense shear, and cavitational flow profiles. Sonication, high pressure homogenization, and microfluidization cover the most prevalent mechanical techniques [43]. The non-mechanical methods rely on producing small droplets of dispersed phase in a mixture of oil, water, and surfactant. Three methods of spontaneous emulsification, phase inversion temperature, and emulsion inversion point are themostwidely used [44,45]. Of course, magnetic stirring is also considered as a low intensity method.
Nanoemulsions possess some principal advantages, including possibility of large-scale production, toxicological safety, and tending to be rapidly digested in the gastrointestinal tract, causing rapidly forming mixed micelles, which can solubilize and transport loaded bioactive compounds into the epithelium cells [40,46]. Also, regarding the physical aspects, nanoemulsions are optically transparent or slightly turbid and have a long-term stability (i.e., changes in the quality of a bioactive over time [47]) and physical stability to aggregation and gravitational separation compared to emulsions. However, the rapid release of

Nanoemulsions have the highest application amongnanocarrier systems to nanoencapsulate the antibacterial ingredients [48–51]. The use of nanoemulsions for the purpose of dealing with the bacterial growth have been explored mostly at three aspects: (1) the antibacterial effect of pure antibacterial agents or nanoemulsionswithout any bioactive incorporated, (2) the antibacterial effect of essential oil-loaded nanoemulsions, (3) the antibacterial effect of one or multiple bioactives-loaded nanoemulsions.
Nanoemulsions may exhibit antibacterial impacts per se. In this regard, the report of Singh et al. [52] signified the importance of O/W nanoemulsions to destroy E. coli cells without any antibacterial substance loading. In their study, atomic force microscopy (AFM) images showed that non-cationised and cationised nanoemulsions without any antibacterial compound led to the 58% and 90% cell lysis, respectively. Similar results were found in another study conducted by the same group [53].
In many studies pertained to the antibacterial-loaded nanoemulsions, researchers have inclined to use essential oils, since they contain a various spectrum of antibacterial compounds; although the nanoemulsification process of essential oils can be problematic as for their volatile nature. Moghimi, et al. [54] prepared a stable nanoemulsion, containing Thymus daenensis essential oil in order to investigate its antibacterial effect against Acinetobacter baumannii. The MIC and MBC values of essential oil-loaded nanoemulsions were 50 and 200 μg/mL, respectively, while these values for pure essential oil were 125 and 2000 μg/mL, respectively, indicating the favorable influence of nanoemulsions in improving the antibacterial effect of Thymus daenensis essential oil against Acinetobacter baumannii. These results were consistent with the study of Paudel, et al. [55].
Nanoemulsions have also been exploited to nanoencapsulate the pure antibacterial compounds. For example, in a study conducted by Ghosh, et al. [56], eugenol was encapsulated within an O/W nanoemulsion, formulated with sesame oil, Twee 80, and water, using ultrasound waves. In this study, S. aureus was exposed to the selected nanoemulsions to determine its antibacterial effect. Fluorescence microscopy findings showed that incorporation of 0.3% eugenol into optimized nanoemulsions resulted in a total loss of viability in approximately 1 min, which was attributed to the membrane permeability alteration. sections.heading: 5. Solid lipid nanoparticles (SLNs) loaded with antimicrobials
sections.text:
SLNs are nanocarriers containing organized crystalline structures. SLNs are mainly derived from O/W emulsions, where the oil (liquid lipid) has been replaced by a solid lipid which forms a crystalline physiological lipid dispersed in aqueous surfactant solution or in water, so that they retain their solid structure at human body and ambient temperatures [14,57]. Substitution of oil with solid lipid demonstrates a milestone in obtaining controlled bioactive release, since the mobility of a bioactive compound in solid lipid structures is basically lower than liquid lipid [58]. Hot homogenization and cold homogenization are two conventionalmethods, used for producing SLNs. In brief, hot homogenization is usually conducted at temperatures over the lipid melting point. A pre-emulsion of the bioactive-loaded lipid melt and an aqueous emulsifier phase is attained using a high shear mixing instrument. The obtained product is a hot O/W emulsion and the cooling of this emulsion results in lipid crystallization and the creation of SLNs. Commonly, 3-5 cycles of homogenization at a pressure of 500-1500 bar are utilized. Cold homogenization was developed to overcome the challenges of the hot homogenization technique. The first stage of preparation in this method is similar to hot homogenization but next steps are different. The lipid melt is cooled instantly by liquid nitrogen or ice for distribution of bioactives in the solid lipid matrix. The bioactive-
loaded solid lipid is then milled using a ball mill or mortar to obtain SLNs. Cold homogenization reduces the thermal exposure of samples. Therefore, it is an ideal method to encapsulate thermolabile compounds [59].
The most common lipids utilized in SLN structures are Precirol, Compritol, cholesterol, cetyl alcohol, glyceryl monostearate, cetylpalmitate, trimyristin, tristearin, and stearic acid [60]. These biocompatible lipids seem to bephysiologicallyfine toleratedwhen administered in vivo. The usage of complex lipids in SLN structures is preferred over similar lipids; the reason is that the application of similar lipids leads to generation of highly crystalized particles with less imperfections, while most bioactive ingredients are localized between lipid layers, between fatty acid chains, and likewise in imperfections [61].
To incorporate bioactive compounds into the SLNs, three models have been proposed, which include homogeneous matrix, bioactive-enriched shell, and bioactive-enriched coremodels [62]. A homogeneous matrix is achieved when exerting the cold homogenization technique or by incorporating very lipophilic bioactive ingredients into SLNs, using the hot homogenization method. The dissolution mechanism controls the release of bioactives in this model. A bioactiveenriched shell is formed when phase separation occurs throughout the cooling process. The burst release happens in this model. A bioactive-enriched core may be formed when bioactive ingredients start to precipitate first. This model causes a membrane controlled release behaviour, which meets the Fick’s law of diffusion [63].
In general, it should be noted that the incorporation of bioactives unto the SLN structures is along with some pros and cons. For example, SLNs propose several advantages, including [64]: (a) controlled bioactive release, (b) possibility of production in large scale, (c) avoid using organic solvents, (d) physiological lipids reduce the SLN toxicity, (e) sustained release of bioactives owing to slow degradation, (f) easy to scale up, sterilize, validate, and gain regulatory approval.
The potential drawbacks of SLNs consist of [58,60,65]: (a) poor bioactive encapsulating capacity, (b) risk of recrystallization and subsequent explosion, (c) high water content of dispersions (70%-95%), (d) unpredictable gelation propensity, (e)weak encapsulation of hydrophilic bioactive ingredients.
The application of SLNs to nanoencapsulate antibacterial agents are more pronounced in the pharmaceutical and clinical sciences. In these fields, SLNs loaded with antibacterial ingredients are mostly used to eradicate infectious bacteria, particularly their biofilms in several parts of body. Biofilm is a microbial-derived sticking community, including cells that can stick irreversibly to surfaces, interfaces, and each other. The living bacteria in biofilms can be resistant to antibacterial substances 1000 times more than free forms of bacteria [66]. SLNs basically deal with biofilms, using two ways, (1) they concentrate the antibacterial agents when contacting with biofilms, (2) the roughness of SLNs (known as nano-roughness) prevent the adhesion of biofilms to body interior surfaces [67]. Also, the charge of SLNs plays a substantial role in destroying biofilms. Since, exopolysaccharide is themain component covering around biofilms (more details at Flemming, et al. [68]), it is difficult for an antibacterial agent to penetrate through the thick layer of polysaccharide to reach targeted bacteria. However, natural polysaccharides are often negatively charged biopolymers, as a result, SLNs with positively charged lipids can interact with biofilm polysaccharides, penetrate within them, and release antibacterial compounds; Also, negatively charged SLNs can release a concentrated amount of antibacterials around the biofilms, although their effects would be lower when using positively charged SLNs [69]. In this regard, Bazzaz, et al. [70] successfully reduced the number of cells in Staphylococcus epidermidis biofilm using formulated SLN-rifampin. Analogous findings were obtained in the study of Shakeri, et al. [71].

The overview of several papers, concerning the antibacterial-loaded SLNs reveals a distinctive gap in utilizing the antibacterial agents. The majority of researches have studied the application of synthetic antibiotics into the SLN structures and only a few reports exist, pertaining the use of natural antibacterial substances. Perhaps the main reason for the limited use of natural antibacterial agents in SLNs is related to the more focus on SLNs in pharmaceutical industries and clinical sciences. Therefore, it can be predicted that with the entry of these structures into other industries such as the food industry, the tendency to use natural antibacterial compounds would increase. One of these few cases is associated to the study of Prombutara, et al. [73], where they nanoencapsulated nisin into the SLNs and reached a sustained antibacterial activity against Listeria monocytogenes and Lactobacillus plantarum.
Lipid-drug conjugate (LDC) is an auxiliary structure for SLNs, basically designed for bioactives, which have the hydrophilic nature. In these nanocarriers, hydrophilic bioactives are loaded on the surface of SLNs, using a fatty acid or phospholipid mediator. In other words, LDC is first formed through grafting the hydrophilic functional groups (e.g., amine groups) of bioactive molecules with the carboxylic groups of some fatty acids (e.g., oleic acid or stearic acid); then the SLN-LDC structure (so-called LDC nanoparticles) is produced by the high pressure homogenization method, followed by melting the LDC in SLN producing lipids [74,75]. Also, LDCs can be accompanied with liposomal structures.
Concerning themicrobial science, the application LDCs is so new and has not yet been addressed well, thus, studies are very scarce in this regard. Only cited example is related to the work of Kalhapure, et al. [76], where they could efficiently encapsulate vancomycin (a highly hydrophilic antibiotic) into SLNs, using linoleic acid as an ion pairing agent. Their findings displayed that the MIC value observed for conjugated vancomycin-SLNs against methicillin-resistant S. aureus was 15.62 μg/mL, which was not comparable with that found for vancomycinloaded SLNs without conjugation (500 μg/mL). The spectacular findings of this study may be a guiding light for researchers interested in this field.

sections.heading: 6. Nanostructured lipid carriers (NLCs) containing antimicrobials
sections.text:
NLCs or oil-loaded SLNs are modified SLN structures in which, less order crystalline or amorphous solid droplets (70% to 95%) are existed along with liquid lipids (0.1% to 30%) [77]. The final aim of NLCformulation is to overcome the SLN limitations and improve the encapsulating efficacy. Since, many bioactives are more solubilized in liquid lipids, the incorporation of oil into the core section of a solid lipid results in the higher capacity of loading and controlled bioactive release. NLCs show a slower polymorphic transition, slower particle growth, and lower crystallinity index. It therefore appears that NLCs dispel disadvantages of SLNs and own the benefits of SLNs together with other lipid nanocarriers [78]. Hence, NLCs might heighten the encapsulation efficiency, bioactive solubility and protection, physical stability, and loading capacity. Also, NLCs contain amorphous structures, resulting in providing a vast space to accommodate the bioactive compounds, therefor, reducing their density and expulsion rate [79].
Some requirements, concerning the lipid blend should be considered before producing NLCs [80,81]. For example, (a) bioactive ingredients should have a satisfactory solubility in liquid lipid, (b) both oils and fats should be spatially incompatible; in the otherwords, they should be miscible at the specific concentrations to avoid the participation of oils in the crystalline matrix of fats, (c) it is necessary to use the lipids, which have the ability to produce nanoparticles, (d) the lipids should be resistant against the chemical degradation, (e) the lipids should not

With concerning these prerequisites, oleic acid and medium chain triglycerides (MCTs) are the most utilized oils for production of NLCs, whereas glyceryl palmitostearate, glyceryl behenate, glyceryl monostearate, stearic acid, and cetyl palmitate are the most common solid lipids used in NLCs [79].
NLCs are structurally classified in three types of imperfect, amorphous, and multiple [6]. The imperfect type NLCs are fabricated by spatially different lipids, causing the increase in their capacity for accommodating bioactive ingredients. In the amorphous type, a mixture of fats with some special lipids, such as hydroxystearate, hydroxyoctacosanyl, isopropyl myristate, or MCTs results in decreasing the expulsion rate. In the multiple model, indicating multiple liquid lipid-in-solid lipid-in-water (O/F/W), the solid matrix contains nano-compartments of liquid lipids, possessing bioactive ingredients. The surrounding of these tiny nano oils by a solid matrix allows the well protection of bioactives and their controlled release.
Production techniques of SLNs and NLCs are similar. Thesemethods, based on the energy needed for production, are categorized into two groups of high and low energy [62,82–85]. The first group is composed of cold/hot homogenization, ultrasonication, and high pressure homogenization; and the second group is consisted of microemulsions, emulsification solvent diffusion, solvent emulsification evaporation, solvent injection, multiple emulsions, phase inversion technique, and membrane contractor technique.
Encapsulation of the antibacterial substances into the NLCs have not been impressively developed, which can be attributed to the newer appearance and exploration of these structures compared to other lipid based nanocarriers. However, the diversity of antibacterial bioactive ingredients nanoencapsulated within NLCs are too much. Essential oils, plant extracts, pure natural and synthetic antibiotics are ingredients, which have been encapsulated within these nanocarriers. Here are some examples: Moreno-Sastre, et al. [86] designed a tobramycinloaded NLC, using hot homogenization method to decrease the viability of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in cystic fibrosis patients. The antibacterial test results displayed aMIC range of 0.5-2 μg/mL and0.5-4 μg/mL for different serotypes of Pseudomonas aeruginosa treated with tobramycinNLCs and pure tobramycin, respectively. Also, Moreno-Sastre, et al. [86] developed a food grade NLC, containing cardamom essential oil by means of cocoa butter and Tween 80. Treated S. aureus with cardamom essential oil-NLCs demonstrated the MIC value of 1100 μg/mL compared to 4400 μg/mL observed for cardamomessential oil emulsion.
Physicochemical, antioxidant, and antibacterial properties of turmeric extract-loaded NLCs were investigated by Karimi, et al. [87]. Regarding the antibacterial activity of designed nanocarriers, the MIC values for turmeric extract-NLCs and pure turmeric extract against E. coliwere found to be 0.073 and 18.75mg/mL, respectively. Other relevant studies have been summarized in Table 5.
7. Combination of antimicrobial-loaded lipid nanocarriers and edible films or coatings
In food area, lipid-based nanocarriers containing antibacterial agents are employed in twoways of free form or incorporated into the packaging films. The application of active packaging films is one of the most promising techniques, avoiding the direct addition of antibacterial substances into foods [88]. These films in addition to protection of foods against environmental conditions, such as oxidation, denaturation, and pH changes can control the release of antibacterial ingredients into foods [89]. However, the incorporation of bioactive ingredients like antibacterial compounds in a non-encapsulated form has negative impacts on optical and transparency characteristics of these films; also several drawbacks, for instances weak miscibility, phase separation, and the chemical or thermal degradation of antibacterial compounds during the film production and forming steps are seen [90]. To overcome these disadvantages, many researchers tend to encapsulate the antibacterial substances in structures like lipid-based nanocarriers
before adding into the packaging films [91]. Although, due to the inhibition effect of encapsulation, the release of antibacterial compoundsmay be reduced and caused a slight drop in the antibacterial function.
For example, Aziz and Almasi [92] successfully produced a whey protein film, containing thyme extract-loaded nanoliposomes. X-ray diffraction (XRD) and scanning electronmicroscopy (SEM) results indicated that the direct addition of thyme extract into whey protein films causes a negative effect on the crystallinity of films as well as increasing the cracks and holes in the film structure. Nevertheless, the nanoencapsulated thyme extract did not display these effects. Though, the antimicrobial activity of the films with the extract-loaded nanoliposomes against Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus was decreased compared to the free thyme extract incorporated films.
Nanoemulsions likewise nanoliposomes are able to be combined with biodegradable antibacterial coatings or films to improve their bactericidal activity [93,94]. In a very interesting research, Severino, et al. [95] used a chitosan coating along with mandarin essential oil-loaded nanoemulsions to control the growth of Listeria innocua on green beans. On the other hand, they employed UV-C, γ-irradiation, and ozonated water treatments to enhance the antibacterial impacts. The best result was achieved when employing the combination of formulated coating and γ-irradiation treatment which reduced bacterial population by 3.3 log CFU/g.
The overview of published papers shows that nanoliposomes and nanoemulsions are the only lipid-based nanocarriers, employed to produce such active films. The relevant works are summarized in Table 6. Structures like SLNs and NLCs have not been used in packaging films or coatings with the purpose of enhancing the antibacterial effects, and it is likely that new researches could be published in this field.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusion and further remarks
sections.text:
Despite the sharp rise in the studies and scientific papers of lipid-based nano carriers and confirmed role of them to encapsulate and improve the solubility, bioavailability, and protection of food bioactive ingredients, a lack of comprehensive study about the antibacterialloaded lipid-based nanocarriers is still observed. In the present paper we tried to provide an overview of recent developments of common lipid-based nanocarriers called nanoliposomes, nanoemulsions, solid lipid nanoparticles, and nanostructured lipid carriers, to encapsulate antibacterial ingredients. These nanocarriers have been proven to reduce the adverse impact of direct addition of antibacterial substances into food systems such as interacting with the physicochemical and sensorial properties of foods and their role on denaturation, cyclization, and oxidation of nutritional ingredients of foods. Each of lipid-based nano carriers possess a unique role to enhance the effect of its loaded antibacterial compounds. Nanoliposomes have a distinctive ability to deliver antibacterial agents into target cells thanks to their similar structures to the cells; Nanoemulsions due to their ease of production even in large scale and their long-term kinetically stability are used more than other lipid nanocarriers to encapsulate antibacterial agents; SLNs have a brilliant advantage of sustained release, which offers a controlled released of antibacterial substances in environment; also it is used as an effective tool to deal with biofilms; NLCs have designed to cover some drawbacks of SLNs by the combination of both fats and oils, offering a high loading capacity to entrap antibacterial bioactives; LDC is an auxiliary structure for SLNs, which are basically designed to encapsulate hydrophilic bioactives using SLNs, although these structures are so new in the field of antibacterial agents delivery. Therefore, it can be predicted that future trends in nanodelivery systemswill elucidate their functions in encapsulating bioactives, particularly antibacterial compounds. In addition to this item, one of the important issues ignored in related studies ismodeling the release kinetics of encapsulated antibacterial substances in cells. Although, the releasing mechanism of bioactives from these nanocarriers in environment has been modeled, but concerning antibacterial-loaded lipid-based nanocarriers, it is needed to investigate
